Description: Call or signal whistle, made of ivory, the large end covered with serpent-skin. The large end is plastered inside with gum stuck with scarlet seeds (abrus). Two small holes are bored through on one edge.
Curator's comments: Register: "The Neam nam. Central Africa. From Petherick collection. See book p.469." The reference is to Petherick's 'Egypt, the Soudan and Central Africa, with explorations from Khartoum on the White Nile to the regions of the equator, being sketches from sixteen years' . The text reads: (on the Azande) ‘Small whistles or calls of ivory or antelope’s horns, attached by a string, are suspended to the neck [eg. Af.2703], and some of the men carry horns made of large elephant tusks [eg Af.282].’
